That's a great plan! A hybrid approach can offer the best of both worlds, and your strategy makes sense. By using wired cameras at the front and back doors, you'll get the reliability and security benefits of wired cameras where it matters most - at the entrances to your home. And by using wireless cameras inside the house, you'll have the flexibility to move them around as needed and avoid the hassle of running cables.

Just make sure to choose cameras that are compatible with each other and with your overall security system, and that you're comfortable with the installation and maintenance requirements of both wired and wireless cameras.

Also, don't forget to consider the following:

* Make sure to position the cameras in a way that they can capture clear footage of faces and license plates, if possible.
* Consider investing in cameras with weather resistance and night vision capabilities, especially for outdoor cameras.
* Choose cameras with high-definition video quality and a wide angle lens to capture more of the scene.
* Consider cameras with motion detection and alerts, so you can receive notifications when motion is detected.
* Make sure to check the storage capacity of your cameras and consider investing in a cloud storage subscription to store footage for a longer period.

By taking these factors into consideration, you'll be able to create a comprehensive and effective home security system that meets your needs and provides you with peace of mind.

Remember, home security is an ongoing process, and it's essential to stay vigilant and monitor your system regularly to ensure it's working effectively. If you have any more questions or concerns, feel free to ask!
